node.title: How can I get the shear stress term of x?
node.bodyText:
Hello, MOOSE developers.
Now I'm trying to make the basic code to certain the compressive and shear stress in the 3D cubic mesh.
My code is like below;
[Mesh]
  type = FileMesh
  file = 3D.e
[]

[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
[]

[Modules/TensorMechanics/Master]
  [./block1]
    strain = FINITE
    add_variables = true
    generate_output = 'stress_xx stress_yy stress_zz stress_xy stress_yz stress_xz'
  [../]
[]

[Materials]
  [./elasticity_tensor]
    type = ComputeElasticityTensor
    C_ijkl = '59.99e9 34.30e9 26.70e9 30.62e9 4.09e9'
    fill_method = axisymmetric_rz
    block = 1
  [../]
  [./stress]
    type = ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress
  [../]
[]

[BCs]
  [./fixed_top]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = z_plus
    value = 0
  [../]
  [./fixed_left]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = 'x_minus x_plus'
    value = 0
  [../]
  [./fixed_right]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = 'y_minus y_plus'
    value = 0
  [../]
  [./Pressure]
    [./comp]
      boundary = z_minus
      function = 1e8*t
    [../]
  [../]
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = 'PJFNK'
  start_time = 0
  n_startup_steps = 1
  end_time = 1
  dt = 0.01
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]

and my mesh file is attached.

please change the name of this file to 3D.e (exodus file).
When I use the above input file and exodus file to run the MOOSE calculation, I can get the result file.
But it doesn't contain "stress_xx stress_xy stress_xz" even though I write those outputs in my input file.

I have checked it using Paraview, but output variables seem like this picture.
Please let me know how can I fix this code.

https://drive.google.com/file/d/1wBiWDIwZL7YFP3eaEk6UZjNFnums9KS-/view?usp=sharing
I share my exodus mesh file using google drive.

Hi,
You are right, you mentioned "stress_xx stress_xy stress_xz" in input file and they were calculated in your results. The point is all of "stress_xx stress_xy stress_xz" components are being saved as a single vector, you can check them in Paraview while other components like "stress_yz are being saved as scalar.
Yeah basically Paraview is grouping stress_xy, stress_xx and stress_xz under stress_x

I appreciate your kind reply!
Then, How can I see the "stress_x" vector as separated scalar terms "stress_xx stress_xy stress_xz" in Paraview?

You could add a suffix in the material property output
click on it and select each component
Thanks a lot! I will try it.

node.title: Summer Internship in Industry
node.bodyText:
Hi
Corning's Scientific Computing group is looking to explore the MOOSE framework. If you are interested in solving industry problems and working with our solid mechanics modelers across the globe, check out the job listing
The start and end dates as well as the duration is pretty flexible! Reach out to me at kavalurav@corning.com if you have any questions

node.title: Question about setting specific initial condition in MOOSE simulation
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
I still have not figured out how to set a specific states as the initial condition in MOOSE simulation.
I want to set the initial condition as the following shape, which is inside the red dotted line. How can I get the concentration and other variables I need from this file and put it in the new simulation? Can anyone give me some advice?

I have tried SolutionUserObject. But it seems it does not work. Does anyone familiar with SolutionUserObject? Or have other methods?
Thank you very much,

Hi,
If you have the initial state data as .csv, I can recommend to use "PropertyReadFile" then define it as a function. Last step, you can use the function as ICs.

node.title: February 2023 News
node.bodyText:
The February 2023 MOOSE Newsletter has been released! A summary of the content is below:

MOOSE Improvements

New MultiApp general field transfers
New parameter: transform a MultiApp frame of reference
Ability to rename parameters in derived objects and new deprecation APIs
Post-processor added to query solid properties
Improved the ability to mark the converged solution invalid
Performance improvements for Navier-Stokes finite volume simulations


Various bug fixes and enhancements

node.title: MooseMatView
node.bodyText:
Hello All
Do you know if moose can output a matrix or a vector? If so, how to output?
Thanks
Are you asking about material property output? You need to do that componentwise. adding outputs = exodus  in the material block might already do the trick.
Thank you very much

If you are asking for outputting the system matrix, you ll want to pass to petsc:  -ksp_view_pmat
See #17089
Thank you very much. I'll try.

node.title: Question about PorousFlowSink
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
I have questions regarding PorousFlowSink.

I can see from the Porous Flow Tutorial Page 06. Adding a trace it is mentioned that it works by setting s=f(t,x) and f as the mass rate with unit kg/m2/s.
Now my question is what is the density referring to? component or fluid or a fluid-component mixture? If it is a mixture, can we inject only components with component density or only fluid with fluid density?  For example, in the Porous Flow Tutorial Page 07. A chemically-reactive tracer, and porosity and permeability changes, only tracer_concentration is set by PorousFlowSink without porepressure.

  [BCs]
   [constant_injection_of_tracer]
     type = PorousFlowSink
     variable = tracer_concentration
     flux_function = -5E-3
     boundary = injection_area
   []
    [constant_outer_porepressure]
     type = DirichletBC
     variable = porepressure
     value = 0
     boundary = rmax
   []
 []


Compared to this PorousFlowSink, I remember when I use a point source with Dirackernel, it always creates some jumps with time at the source position, but this PorousFlowSink seems to give a very nice behavior without any jumps. What is the main reason resulting in that? Does PorousFLowSink only work at boundary terms?
Dear @GiudGiud , could you please help me have a look at this? Thank you.

I m not really a Porous Flow expert. It would be better for @WilkAndy to weigh in.
Though I m thinking the answer to 1 will be in the tutorial or the docs of the module

The density will be the fluid density at those conditions. If adding a component doesn't alter the density (like in the example you mentioned) then density of just that calculated for the fluid at those pressure and temperature conditions.
The sink bc is applied over the length of the boundary specified, instead of a single point like a Dirac kernel, S which probably explains the smoother change.

node.title: What kernel(s) allow coupling to a first order derivative?  Or square of first order derivative?
node.bodyText:
I'm looking for an AD kernel which does the equivalent of coupling a time derivative to diffusion, but for the first derivative wrt x rather than the second derivative.
dy/dt = A dy/dx
rather than
dy/dt = D d^2y/dx^2
It looks like PrimaryConvetion and Convected Mesh have the right sort of idea, but are too specific to particular applications.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/kernels/PrimaryConvection.html
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/kernels/ConvectedMesh.html
I'm looking for a nice simple generic kernel which but can't see anything obvious in the names.  Also I need to be able to specify the coefficient A as a material property, and for the kernel to work with AD.
Does a kernel to meet my needs exist?

P.S.  What would be even better is a kernel for:
dy/dt = A [dy/dx]^2
MatGradSquareCoupled looks like it could do this, but again maybe specific to a particular application and doesn't seem to have an AD version.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/kernels/MatGradSquareCoupled.html

Hello
MatGradSquareCoupled seems to do exactly what you want except it s not AD.
You can mix AD and non-AD kernels, the only issue is the AD-status of the material property. This kernel will only accept a non-AD one, and will retrieve the derivatives of the material properties to help form the Jacobian.
So you can either:

rewrite that kernel with AD. This should be fairly simple.
use that kernel, duplicate your AD material property with a non-AD version and create the derivatives manually

Guillaume

Thank you!  This is really helpful!
When you say "create the derivatives manually" is this something that I have to do myself by doing hand calculations outside MOOSE and/or adding further lines of code for each derivative.  Or does MOOSE do these calculations itself just "manually" rather than using the automatic differentiation option.
I'm assuming the second one, but just want to be sure.

Hello
So yes when people are making regular material properties and need the derivatives, they usually need to do the hand calculation outside of MOOSE, then create a new material property with a name like "dD_dT" and use that as the property.
UNLESS it s a simple parsed expression and in this case the DerivativeParsedMaterial can do that for you.
Guillaume
but tbh the easy option here is to copy paste the kernel and make it AD. Just need to some these two letters in a bunch of places

node.title: An independent elastoplasticity (CamClay) model for soil mechanics
node.bodyText:
I am writing to inform you of my recent development of an AD constitutive material with applications in soil mechanics, specifically the CamClay model. After successfully testing this code in the C++ library Deal.II, I have decided to develop the AD version in MOOSE to add additional features without the need for derivatives and Jacobians.
Despite attempting to fit the model into different subclasses of MOOSE to minimize manipulation, my first attempt using the ADGeneralizedRadialReturnMapping was unsuccessful due to its tie to the elasticity tensor, which conflicts with CamClay's unique elasticity tensor update. As a result, I have tried directly implementing the CamClay model as an ADStrainIncrementBasedStressUpdate. However, although I have successfully compiled the code, it does not converge for unknown reasons. I am particularly confused by the interdependencies of parameters, such as _stress[_qp], _incremental_strain[_qp], and others that must be provided.
To diagnose the issue, I have run several tests and have concluded that the problem occurs in the first step of the analysis before entering the plastic region. I suspect that the inconsistency of the initial stress and strain may be at fault. To elaborate, the CamClay model begins with an initial confining pressure (e.g., -100kPa) and then applies a deviatoric stress on top of a biaxial plain strain sample from the top.
If you have any recommendations or advice on how to resolve this issue or any potential oversights, please do not hesitate to let me know. I appreciate any help and am eager to resolve this issue as soon as possible.
Mahyar
Does initial stress distribute in the model properly?  can you paste here the initial stress state.

node.title: Applying a pressure
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I have applying a pressure as BC as :
[./impact]
    #type = pressure
    #type = FunctionDirichletBC
    type =  FunctionNeumannBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = 'impact'
    function = '200*t'
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
  [../]

in fact the compuation finishs but without applying anything : everything is zero. The same results obtained with type = pressure.
Of course to check the mesh I have tried FunctionDirichletBC and obtained the expected results.
thanks in advance.

I suggest you use Pressure Action to set up pressure BC.
If you want to use pressureBC, I remember you need to add component which should be 1 for your case.

like this ?
[./impact]
    #type = FunctionDirichletBC
    type =  PressureBC
    variable = disp_y
    component = 1
    boundary = 'impact'
    function = '200*t'
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
  [../]

Already tried and gave zero everywhere.

[BCs]
[./Pressure]
    [./Side1]
      boundary ='impact'
      function = '1.0*t'
      displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
    [../]
[../]

does not work neither.

Could you attach your input file here?
I do not know your unit system and time. It could be the function `1.0*t' is too small. I suggest you consider a larger constant value to verify if the pressure is actually applied or not.

could not be this, since I have nothing happening (excatly zero everywhere).
The bridge.i example with a pressure applied on the top is working for me !
Is there anything holding the system on another side?

[Mesh]
file = multi6_4.inp
construct_side_list_from_node_list=true
[]

[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
[]



[Modules]
  [./TensorMechanics]
    [./Master]
      [./mech]
        add_variables = true
        strain = SMALL
        additional_generate_output = 'stress_yy stress_xx stress_xy'
      [../]
    [../]
  [../]
[]
[BCs]
[Pressure]
    [Side1]
      boundary ='top'
      function = '1.0*t'
      factor = 5e5
      displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
    []
[]
 [bottom]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = 'right'
    value = 0.0
  []

 [leftx]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = 'left'
    value =0.0
   []
[lefty]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary ='left'
    value =0.0
   []
[]
What is the initial residual value at the first time step?

What is the initial residual value at the first time step?

Maybe the second time step, because your function is 0 at t=0.

@jiangwen84 how does it guess the component here?
[BCs]
[Pressure]
    [Side1]
      boundary ='top'
      function = '1.0*t'
      factor = 5e5
      displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
    []
[]

What is the initial residual value at the first time step?

Maybe the second time step, because your function is 0 at t=0.

I am not solving for pressure, just want to apply a load.

It is all because loose precision !
With a nl_abs_tol =1.0e-8 everything is working fine. I am working with
international units and find that 1.0e-3 is fine for absolute and relative
tolerance. Do not know why I should go so far to have something correct for
a linear elastic computatio.
By the way, what is the integration method used locally (for material) in
nonlinear analysis?
Regards
